title: Intersecting Chords
content:
The **Product of Segments of Chords** theorem states that when two chords of a circle intersect at a point P:

$$PA \cdot PB = PC \cdot PD$$

This elegant result says that the product of the segments is the same for *any* chord through P. The product depends only on P's position relative to the circle, not on which direction the chord goes.

title: The Main Theorem
content:
**Theorem (Euclid III.35)**:

If two chords AB and CD of a circle intersect at point P, then:
$$PA \cdot PB = PC \cdot PD$$

**Proof idea**: Both products equal the absolute value of the power of P:
1. $PA \cdot PB = |\text{pow}(P)|$
2. $PC \cdot PD = |\text{pow}(P)|$
3. Therefore $PA \cdot PB = PC \cdot PD$

The power is an invariant of the point's position relative to the circle.

title: Algebraic Approach
content:
**Vieta's Formulas Approach**:

Parameterize points on a chord through P in direction $\vec{d}$:
$$Q(t) = P + t\vec{d}$$

A point is on the circle of radius r centered at origin iff:
$$|P + t\vec{d}|^2 = r^2$$

Expanding (with $|\vec{d}| = 1$):
$$t^2 + 2t\langle P, \vec{d}\rangle + |P|^2 - r^2 = 0$$

By **Vieta's formulas**, the product of roots is:
$$t_1 \cdot t_2 = |P|^2 - r^2$$

Since distances are $|t_1|$ and $|t_2|$, we get $|t_1| \cdot |t_2| = r^2 - |P|^2$ for interior points.

title: Special Case: Center
content:
When P is at the **center** of the circle:

- Every chord through P is a diameter
- Both segments have length r (the radius)
- The product is $r \cdot r = r^2$

This confirms our formula since pow(center) = $0^2 - r^2 = -r^2$, and $|\text{pow}| = r^2$.

This is the *maximum* value of PA * PB for any interior point.

title: The Converse
content:
**Converse Theorem**:

If lines AB and CD intersect at P, and:
$$PA \cdot PB = PC \cdot PD$$

then A, B, C, D all lie on a common circle (they are **concyclic**).

This is a powerful criterion for proving four points lie on a circle. The converse follows because equal products imply equal power, which determines a unique circle.

title: From Euclid to Steiner
content:
**Euclid (300 BCE)**: The theorem appears as Proposition 35 in Book III of the Elements. Euclid proved it using similar triangles formed by the chords.

**Jakob Steiner (1826)**: Systematized the "power of a point" concept, unifying:
- Intersecting chords (interior point)
- Two secants (exterior point)
- Secant and tangent
- Two tangents

All are manifestations of the same invariant!
